texts.definition: Rule systems that affect the game state so that future similar affects will have greater impact on the game state.
markups: <style="Definition">Rule systems that affect the game state so that future similar affects will have greater impact on the game state.</style>

Players that perform well in a game typically receive some form of reward. When the reward makes performing the same action again easier, this creates a <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loop</style>. However, the "positive" aspect simply denotes an increase and not a positive effect for the player; another type of <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loop</style> in a game is to provide harder challenges to players that succeed with the existing ones.

Wikipedia has a [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_feedback page] on <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style>. The chapter ''Games as Cybernetic Systems'' in Rules of Play<ref name="rop"/> look extensively at positive and negative feedback loops and their use in games.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monopoly">Monopoly</link></style> both exhibit <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> in that players that have a lead in number of pieces or money (respectively) tend to expand that lead more and more until they have won the games. Managing to build effective decks in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominion">Dominion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mystic%20Vale">Mystic Vale</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Thunderstone">Thunderstone</link></style> lets players get better cards that further improves the effectiveness of those decks.

Games that are built very strictly around one <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loop</style> include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cookie%20Clicker">Cookie Clicker</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cow%20Clicker">Cow Clicker</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Progress%20Quest">Progress Quest</link></style>.

Providing players with the possibility to create <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style> is a typical reason to have <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> in games. A general approach to creating <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> is to make use of <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or effects of player actions where the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> and effects also make the actions easier to do in the future. Since such <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> often take the form of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> (or access to <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>), the use of <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> heavily affect how these work in a game.

Quite naturally, <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style> work against the pattern if applied to <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> affecting the relevant player actions (by definition <style="Link"><link="negative-feedback-loops">Negative Feedback Loops</link></style> related to the same parts of the game state also work against the pattern).

Several different <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> can exist in a game. For example, in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominion">Dominion</link></style> players can have <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> related to gaining <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> with actions or purchase ability or those related to gaining <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> that increase their <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style>. Knowing when to start focusing on the latter due to the game being about to end is a skill in this game, and shows how the presence of the <style="Link"><link="construction-scoring-phase-shift">Construction/Scoring Phase Shift</link></style>

<style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> can create a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Runaway%20Leader">Runaway Leader</link></style> and thereby also <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style>. For this reason, <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> work against <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style> (while <style="Link"><link="negative-feedback-loops">Negative Feedback Loops</link></style> can work for them). However, such situations also promote <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Predictable%20Gameplay%20Time">Predictable Gameplay Time</link></style> since one of the players may be likely to be able to exploit the  <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loop</style> before certain amount of gameplay time has occurred.

When the <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> are focused upon the challenges players met (rather than players' <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style>, etc. that lead to a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Runaway%20Leader">Runaway Leader</link></style>), the pattern can create

<style="Link"><link="ever-increasing-difficulty">Ever Increasing Difficulty</link></style> in a game. Using <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style> to create <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> often makes <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> exist in games as well as offering players <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> when that effort is connected to making the <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> occur. When the <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style> occurs through <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, the <style="CurrentLink">Positive Feedback Loops</style> that occur can also give rise to <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> (if they can be lost) and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> (in that one may need to know when to collect on one's <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>).
